newsitem.title: UK: SMITH&NEPHEW SAYS DOING WELL AGAINST RIVALS.
newsitem.headline: SMITH&NEPHEW SAYS DOING WELL AGAINST RIVALS.

text.p: Smith & Nephew said on Tuesday it was performing well against its competitors, particularly in the U.S., where sales grew seven percent in the first half of 1997.
The British healthcare group's position was mainly boosted by the constant flow of new products onto the market, chief executive Chris O'Donnell said.
"We got our new products rolling strongly in the U.S.," he said.
Endoscopy sales grew 12 percent due to a new shaver system, while a series of new artificial knees grabbed a five percent share of the U.S. market, O'Donnell said.

He said overall price pressure in the U.S. was subsiding after a very tough 1996. Average price levels came down three percent last year, but the decline so far this year was "a bit less than half that," O'Donnell said.
"Clearly the trend is upwards," he added.
In sharp contrast to the bright picture in the U.S., business in Europe deteriorated as governments tightened budgets to meet monetary union requirements.
European sales were flat in the first half after nine percent growth in 1996, O'Donnell said.
"We've seen a significant change," he said.
But Smith & Nephew has succeeded in winning market share in Germany, its biggest market on the European continent. In France it held or marginally gained market share, O'Donnell said.
Smith & Nephew plans to have factories in India and China, but the brunt of its Asian investments is aimed at boosting its sales force across the continent.
Smith & Nephew earlier reported an 11.75 percent fall in first-half profits which were badly hit by the pound's strength.
"But we believe the underlying business is healthy and will continue to grow going forward," O'Donnell said.
